pros: Salary higher than the market average in the position.
cons:
Relatively, higher pay to buy your time. Long working hours and no work-life balance have become a label for the company. I accept OT, but most OT jobs after office hours and weekends are for those team meetings or training rather than solving the problem. You are expected to reply to the chat message or call at midnight and the weekend. It may be suitable for graduates but definitely is not good for a family man. 

Furthermore, it's a very hierarchical company. For example, the company combined regular and contractor employees. These discriminating treatments drive a wedge between teams. Even regular staff have different title rankings in the company. It calls it an MNC, but it doesn't. It seems has less autonomy in the local team. We always need to ask for the HQ team. 

What I don't like most is their so call military management. For example, if you reached the office late after 9 am, even 1 min. The attendance system will send an alert to you, and you must declare it to your manager and explain why you are late.

review_title: Fake it and make it environment in Singapore.
pros:
Lots of learning opportunities also because it’s related to getting thrown in the dark.

Backend support in HQ is strong but otherwise you will need to handle the customers yourself. Goes along way to establish good rapport with your supervisor and bigger bosses.
cons:
You may get thrown in the dark but if are resourceful, you’ll always find a way.

Hours can be long and meetings are common on Fri nights or weekends. Additionally, extra hours are required if you wanna improve or self learn.

Depending on your rapport with the immediate supervisor, life can be bearable or hellish. 

Role involves a lot of and I mean a lot of independent work. If you’re experiencing a major issue, don’t expect anyone to help you especially because everyone else is usually busy. There are nice people willing to help along the way but don’t count on it.

Chinese is a must when conversing internally. Otherwise for external, most of the customers are Singapore based and speak English.

pros:
Extremely fast pace and busy working environment - (You can be well trained like a working soldier)

Multi language working environment - ( You can improve your mandarin)
cons:
- Very bad reward, expect to be mentally imbalanced when you see permanent staff take huge bonus but you earn nothing with same working load or even heavier load- (Huawei Singapore recruit engineer in Contract basic) 
- Very political working environment (官僚环境） - You boss have super power that he can rate you but you can never rate you - Technically, he has super power over you. (For example- he can give you bad performance rating if he does not like you even you had contribute remarkable achievement.
- No career progression - just expect to stay as an contract engineer for many years. (probably after ten years you got chance to convert to permanent staff). Of course, the line manager will try his best to make you go after you service for two to three years to ensure his position stability.
- The so called great reward rumours of Huawei only applicable to those who worked in HQ.

review_title: MNC that provides preferential treatment to mainland Chinese,sidelining local hires
pros:
Good exposure to a very localised China's business culture without having work in China itself. One will learn how to work with mainland Chinese and receive extensive practice of mandarin (spoken) and written Chinese. 
Despite the general lack of work-life balance, the unique chinese culture is such that if you are successful at getting into key management's good books,  you can literally get by with doing minimal work for years. Similarly, if you get into their bad books, no amount of achievements can propel you upwards. A highly political place
cons:
Other than a serious lack of work life balance, where employees are expected to work overtime, weekends and even public holidays, there is a huge disregard for local staff ie. Non mainland Chinese hires. 
Local employees receive lower if not no variable bonus (if they are under another hiring scheme). 
Promotion and relocation opportunities  are also meant for mainland Chinese, usually regardless of performance. 
Despite it being an MNC,  the office is staffed predominantly with mainland Chinese, many of whom received PR or citizenship. You will be expected to communicate in Chinese and prepare work documents and emails in Chinese. Lack of diversity makes the environment very stifling and rigid.

review_title: They have a ranking for person with the highest overtime clocked!
pros: Good pay, broad product range, opportunity to move between departments and countries and hence if you are young, then it is likely a good place to start.
cons: No work life balance, expected to keep working late into the night and employees are rewarded based on the perception that they are working hard (i.e. Long hours). Low number of leave days. Crazy amount of processes and meetings (at odd hours) and no formal training! Not recommended for mid-career employees who have young family and working spouse. Very regimental and top down approached. It feels like the army where the regular career soldiers are represented by the staff from PRC and the reservist represented by the local staff. The career soldier will work very hard because their next posting depends on it and the locals really treat this as part of work/life and while they are serious about their work, they can never compete with the career soldiers because they have family commitments.

review_title: Not suitable for one with family commitment
pros: Plenty of learning opportunities, good bonus, change department head every 3-5 years so good or bad boss wont last long. Huge team in regional and HQ for your queries but they may not able to give you exact answer, but they are very kind to assist you. Very huge learning database, you can find many things that you need inside so less dependancies on counterparts support
cons: Meetings and training after working hours or weekend, all things last minute, arrangement and cancellation, no respect for people’s personal life and time. If you have family commitment, its hard, the culture do not consider your situation. Many processes, and because of the turn over then not everyone is familiar with it. The overtime is not due to getting unfinished work done but more due to the pressure from management that need to overtime to show that you really works hard ..............

review_title: No respect to local staff and communist oriented mindset
pros: Good place to learn new technologies and learn Chinese.
cons:
Forcing staff to stay in office till late (10pm) if not will deem attitude problem, implemented clock in clock out system, hence even how late u work in office, the next morning I can’t late for 1 sec. Local management purposely arrange meeting / training in the weekend and force staff back to office
Management too bloated, have the mindset that Huawei equip is leading and ahead of others vendor, hence operator have only choice which is Huawei only.

The local management don’t like employee to smile and be happy in office, they will deem is employee attitude issue as not serious in office.

Most employee in office is expat from China, if not is China PR or China converted citizen, the management not welcome local and promote local to management

pros:
You will meet some nice colleagues that may become your afterwork friends. 
You may get good colleagues that tell you you have done a great job giving you a sense of appreciation. But not from your boss. The employees are efficient when comes to replying and they expect to get work done very quickly within 24hrs. That goes the same for me too since it is the expectations of everyone it seems no matter. They held meetings to improve their internal systems, SOP. etc. They have good security in terms of IT.
cons:
Manager promises increment year after year but it didn't happen. Overwork, overload with false promises. Aside from that they called you via mobile, text you, email you, intranet to you despite after office hrs so you are bombarded with alot requests regardless of timezone differences and last min request. The Chinese are very bad in planning and have very little consideration for other department who service their administration needs. 
You may see some chinese who called themselves as leaders shouting, yelling at their subordinate. Depending on which region and what people are transferred to your region. Some region is very lucky -no such people but some aren't. They seem to have a practice to bring a local chinese  and fire the foreigner afterwards. Though not always but for higher ranking especially.
1. be sure you are in protection under the labor law
2. be sure you negotiate ur employment terms and Conditions before joining
(talking doesnt count)
3. be sure you have a good boss because your salary appraisal is all under his hands. For e.g. if you done a better job than him, and others recognized your work but not your superior, than you are strucked.
4. be sure you asked about your career prospects. In this area, they allow room for you to grow.

review_title: Service Manager in Huawei Device department
pros: The job load is quite suitable for the persons who want to understand the company operation flow. And the job can train the staffs to be a versatile talent and competitive.
cons: Working in Huawei means a spate of overtime. Often the staffs would leave office around 8PM every day. The work and life balance is very bad compared to other companies.

pros:
A great platform to learn, have sufficient of resources to learn. Well arranged online/cloud database. You can extract every information, learning materials from its own database.
Great opportunity in self development.  Great bonus.
cons:
Working hours can be very long > 10 hours depends on department and job role. 
Lots of Policy and procedure need to follow.

pros: Basically, you got quite a bit of free time for leisure. Go learn golf, pick up something you like, interact with customers and be close to them. You can practically grow old and retire here if you do not mind the miserable salary and horrid long hours.
cons:
Salary - Forget about fat bonuses if you are not from China (Not even Asians!!). The salary scale tipped the point of below mediocre and expect yourself to be like this for years to come. If you are holding a CHINA passport, yes there are perks beyond imagination like private shares, but if you are not, stop dreaming and look the other way. 
Management - What's that again? That doesn't even exist!! You would likely be managed by some young chap who would be 10 - 15 years younger than you, sitting in his spanking office (with a door - CLOSED) and you?.. outside in a cube with the rest of the low-lifers. Customer meetings? - handle it yourself, they won't follow you when the meeting's agenda is about putting fighting fire. Some excuses like they would be busy the whole day or having other meetings. Good luck, buddy!
Career path - The only path that you would likely see is a path of flat line, no opportunities, no learning curve, just pure work.
Work/life balance - You would likely be in a volatile situation, depending on your position. Product people are ok with some life. Sales/ Accounts people would need to find ways around this.
Culture/Value - Yes, their culture, regardless of any country. The whole work environment is filled to the brim with propaganda posters supporting their own country and with gaudy colors of red and white, making you riddled with the fact that if you are in YOUR own country or Theirs! They value you as a hard worker, like stray canine on a leash.

review_title: Great Company Culture and Supportive Environment
pros: Stability: Typically offers more stability than working for oneself or being self-employed. You have a steady paycheck and a consistent workload. Benefits: Many offer benefits such as health insurance, retirement plans, paid time off, and other perks that can improve your quality of life. Collaboration: Working in this company means you get to collaborate with other professionals, which can help you learn from others, share ideas, and build a strong professional network. Resources: Company have access to resources that individuals may not have, such as advanced technology, specialized equipment, and research and development teams. Recognition: Working in this company can offer opportunities for recognition, awards, and other forms of recognition that can boost your confidence and help you advance in your career.
cons: Poor work-life balance: Many companies require long hours and expect employees to be available 9Hr in the company and No WFH option Limited growth opportunities: Some companies have limited opportunities for career advancement, which can make it difficult for employees to progress in their careers.

review_title: High level of bureaucracy, no work/life balance
pros: High salary, experience of cooperation with colleagues of another national culture.
cons: You will have to draw high KPIs even in case of bad work results. This is the main skill you must have if you work for this company. You will be supported in this issue by managers at all levels, not only national or regional. If you don't do it - don't expect any promotion and it may be real risk to lose the job. Disrespect and even cruel approach to employees, their health, and their private life. This employer may announce "strict" quarantine (here I talk about COVID-19) and at the same time demand that employees come and work in the office. Both local and HQ HR and EHS ignored the violation. But their reports about care about employees and fighting pandemic were really-really nice. That is just one of many negative examples typical for this employer.

job_title: E-Commerce Manager in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: 1. Competitive Salary and Benefits: Huawei provides competitive salaries and benefits packages, including health insurance, bonuses, and other compensation structures that are highly competitive with other multinational companies. 2. Stability: Huawei offers job security to its employees, providing a stable working landscape in which employees can excel in their positions without fear of immediate layoffs or restructuring. Many of its employees have been with the company for over 10 years. 3. Career Opportunities: The company offers generous opportunities for growth and development within its organization at all levels, varying from internships to senior management positions. It has an excellent training program for new hires and developing established talent alike. 4. International Network: With a presence in more than 170 countries worldwide, Huawei is able to attract talented workers from across the globe and develop relationships with them through global initiatives like employee exchange programs and international conferences/programs.
cons: 1. Long Working Hours: In order to keep up with the demands of their industry, Huawei requires longer working hours which may seem excessive or tiring after long spells at the office each day. 2. Intense Competition: Competition is fierce within the company with many young professionals vying against each other for advancement opportunities or better pay scales raising stress levels among some of its employees on occasion.. 3. Cultural Challenges: As an internationally-focused organization characterized by cultural diversity, there are certain challenges that arise such as language barriers between different ethnicities making it difficult to communicate effectively sometimes leading to misunderstandings or conflict resolution issues.,

cons: Chinese leaders are incompetent. It is not at all European and not at all logical any system. You borrow your own money for customer dinners, which you get back months later, if you paid in euros, that's how you did it. They offer the minimum, but expect the maximum. There are Hungarian leaders who are well paid, they believe that this is a good place, but they no longer do meaningful work. I have no idea how this company is still viable. You can earn well only with overtime, of which there is plenty. Chinese colleagues speak English like an eight-year-old Indian. The restroom is dirty because they do their business like at home, that's why all the china is like that. For crows and spitting, munching. If you want to find out what it's like to work in China, go ahead, Huawei is waiting!

The ability to progress careerwise is solely determined by your direct supervisor, as they get to propose your promotions, salary adjustments, and bonuses. Therefore your fate careerwise is dependent on them. Therefore your colleagues might get astronomical salary increments up to 2-3 times a year, yet some have not had a salary increase in over 2-3 years. Your work grade level doesn't determine your responsibilities and pay. ie you may be in the same job grade but earn different salaries. Some roles don't allow for creativity or thinking outside the box. Therefore the longer you stay in those roles limits your ability to transition to other roles smoothly and therefore, some transferable skills may be lacking as you are programmed to think and do things in a certain way. Some discussions/ meetings take place in Chinese secluding those who don't speak

pros:
- You work at one the biggest tech companies
- Managers and team member are good and helpful.
cons:
- Low salary. They should be more than average Turkisk company. Generally those who have been at longer gain less salary. While you try to get like 20% raise someone who just got into Huawei can get much higher
- You might see many people with Assistant level although they have been working more than 2 years. It's because it is hard to get higher levels inside. If you are joining company outside you will probably get better level.
- While transfering from Outsource to Huawei (or reverse) you will lost all the benefits. For example if you have 20 days annual leave and you transfered your payroll you will have 14 again. They act like you just joined Huawei.
- Slow decision and affects. While you suffer from low salary, sodexo etc. they implement solutions much later.
- Raise is not very frequent and hard to get. Everything is performance for Huawei. Even if they will make a inflation raise they check your performance grade.
- Fixed holidays. What I mean is even if you don't want to use your annual leave they make you use it (mostly used for holiday like feast of sacrifice or ramadan). It's also done by some other companies but I think it's not ok.
- Working with Chinese people might be challenging. Some of them really easy to work with but some of them realy hard to work with
- Generaly busy but work life balance can be frustrating on some projects.

pros: It looks good on your resume. Nothing else is good in here.
cons: There is serious racial discrimination in this company. Chinese employees always earn more than Turkish employees. Some Chinese earn more than their Turkish Managers while working as Specialist under them. Another example for racial discrimination; If you're a Chinese who lives in Turkey, you can be anything at Huawei. Your background, education and experience is not important. If you're unemployment Chinese person, you can become HR BP in here in one day even if you don't know anything about HR. The only important thing is being Chinese native speaker. That's all. But if they try to hire local Turkish employee, they suddenly become too curious and start to ask difficult questions in the job interview. There is a Chinese cafeteria that only Chinese employee can eat there. Turkish local employees is not allowed :) Chinese managers do not care employee motivation at all. They're thinking like "They can go If they want to, we will not do anything for them to stay". I heard that sentence with my own ears :) They do not follow inflation rates, they do not raise salaries, they do not want to work hybrids etc. In short, they ignore all employee requests. The funny thing is, when an employee tries to quit, they suddenly start to panic and tell lies to get them to stay. They're really difficult people to understand. Some departments work from office while some of them working as hybrid. However, If you're working in a department which works 5 days from office, you will realise that even 5 days working from office is not enough for your Chinese Manager. They also want you to come to the office on Saturday for an unnecessary 6 hours meeting and they do not accept any "excuse" for not coming. Lastly, mobbing, mobbing everywhere. In every department, in every office. DO NOT come here.

review_title: Work for half of your net worth.
pros: - Being able to work remotely. - Salaries are paid on time.
cons:
- The company is shrinking, the HQ either cancels or takes over projects from Turkey. At this point, they don't even care about their most capable developers leaving the company because they have a very low budget and the R&D director in Turkey doesn't have any authority. 
- Almost everyone at the company is looking for jobs. People got no commitment nor respect for the company anymore. The general morale in the company is very low. 
- Directors are leaving for better pay even if it's a lower position.
- Almost all of the developers are interns and juniors. Therefore, there are many quality issues and bugs in the projects. You will never come across best practices. All they care about is creating a product and because of the incapability of the teams, they will force you to do overtime.
- Too much bureaucracy and useless exams which will not help your carreer. 
- The HQ decides for everything and the teams in Turkey work as servants. 
- You have to deal with Chinese project managers from the HQ who neither can't speak English, nor will they understand you. If your English is fluent, they will warn you to speak bad English. 
- Depending on the HQ for almost all of the projects is really painful. 
- You are generally paid half of your net worth compared to similar positions in Turkey. If you are a fresh graduate, you will be working for little above the minimum wage. If you are a senior or a manager, you will be working for a junior's salary outside. The last average salary increase was 35% while the yearly inflation rate is about 300%. 
- Managers earn the same amount as developers. 
- Nor managers, neither the directors don't have any significant authority. - Weekly hero reward is a 50TL D&R gift card.
- 80TL sodexo per day. 
- Baklava for the feast.
- Biscuits and soft drinks at the R&D, and hopefully 200TL sodexo in the new year's eve. 
*P.S. If the cons I have mentioned don't make you laugh, then you definitely belong in Huawei :-)

pros: Entry-level positions might be a good choice for fresh graduates. If you have more than 1 year of experience DON'T even think about applying here.
cons:
I have worked here for years and here are my observations:

- Very low salaries
- Managers always lie about salary increases and THEY DON'T CARE ABOUT THE INFLATION in Turkey. You can't get INFLATION raise even if you are a high performer.
- You will be an underpaid employee after a while.
- Sometimes they can't raise your salary because of the company policies and you have to be an outsourced employee to get the raise. You will lose all of your annual leaves after transferring.
- Managers and directors sometimes get extra bonuses but you won't hear and 
 get any. Also, these amounts are very high.
- It is highly possible to work on different projects every ~6-8 months and those projects could be very boring. Some projects have no coding tasks. This is AWFUL.
- Hierarchy
- Most of the Chinese colleagues can't speak English, unfortunately.
- No overtime pay
- High turnover rates
- Most of the skilled guys are resigned
- Almost no activities organized by the company. You probably will feel like a robot.
- There is no discount for the employees on their products

pros:
•	Worked on amazon Web Services ( EC2, ELB, VPC, S3, IAM, CloudWatch, SNS).
•	Creating IAM users with key pairs.
•	Installed and Setup Git Repository (Version Control System) at client side.
•	Log Analysis, Maintaining documents of production server error log's reports.
•	Providing data for weekly and monthly report to senior management.
•	Monitor Production Server Health of different parameters (CPU Load, Physical Memory, Swap Memory, Hard disk and response time) via Nagios.
•	Load Balancer : AWS Load balancer (ELB)
•	Experienced on working Database Service, CloudWatch, CloudFront, Identity and Access Management, Command Line Interface, S3 Bucket with AWS services such as EC2 Instances, Elastic Load Balancers, Auto scaling.
cons:
•	Worked on AWS IAM for creating new roles, groups, users and assigning policies to groups and users.
•	Created the snapshots, AMI for the AWS data backup’s along with the data at rest security within AWS.
•	Setup different volume types of AWS Elastic Block Storage (EBS) based on the requirement. 
•	Created alarms in CloudWatch service for monitoring the server performance, CPU Utilization, disk usage etc.
•	Also, responsible for project management, team leadership and mentoring team members across projects and application/production support.
•	Used AWS cloud services like EC2, VPC, Auto Scaling to build highly scalable, secure and flexible systems to handle expected and unexpected load bursts.
•	Uploaded and bundled own customized AMI to S3 amazon bucket. Mounted S3 bucket with EC2 Instance and used the life cycle policies to move the data to Glacier.
•	Mounted S3 and Glacier on windows server for maintenance purposes. Integrated web portal and associated users with S3 bucket.
•	Monitoring of the servers for its availability, capacity usage, hardware and OS errors and failures.
•	Remote system administration of various virtual & physical resources.

review_title: MRO Datacom Engineer-Great job for youngsters who don't sleep at night
pros:
Depending on which account team that you will be joining but:
-Less office politic environment where you can focus on your work
-Massive and well-documented resources available in Chinese for you to learn on your own. You are expected to learn on your own.
-Teamwork exist: if you need help you need to raise it up, your colleague will help you, of course, help offering goes both ways. Engineers are generally well supported by HQ experts as well
-Less micromanage by superior due to the amount of work/responsibility assigned to each person will ensure you don't have the time to focus on other things except your work
cons:
-Awful work-life balance, be prepared to work over the weekend occasionally without compensation. Being said, they try not to disturb you over the weekend
-Acceptance of night work is a must as maintenance window is at night to reduce service impact to telco subscribers. Depending on the scale/seriousness of the night operation, occasionally that spans from midnight to next day morning. You might even receive calls during your sleep if things don't go well
-Strict and sometimes bureaucratic procedure will cause you to spend less than doing the actual work

review_title: Get ready for a stressful life
pros: High pay. Free expensive meals and bubble tea(if you go to office).
cons:
- Chinese company culture. Not easy to move up higher as they will still use china Chinese as leader. 
- No work life balance. 996 is norm. The high pay is to cover your OT. 
- Not flexible at all. if you late by 1 minute at 9am to the office. Deduct salary. If you come early and start early, you cannot go back early. Or not, deduct salary.
- People are quite selfish. All the people will tell you, "explore it and think, then only ask me when you really don't know." When ask, they will say why you so stupid. 
- During probation, no annual leaves, can only apply unpaid leaves. And if you apply before or after public holiday/weekend, they count that public holiday/weekend as unpaid day as well. So in other way, don't apply leave during probation. 
- No benefits. No dental, Optical or any benefits. They will say that the pay itself covers everything. Therefore, fight for a higher pay when joining. If not it is not worth it. 
- Politics non-stop. Very super duper toxic. 
- Travelling to other countries is not what you think. No hotel. No high allowance. and have to proof you bought the Cheapest flight ticket. You have to share room with other people in their hostel. If someone caught Covid... Congrats....
- If you worked for Europe/US culture company before, not encourage to join as the culture is really different and hard to adapt.

C&Q system (mitigated opinion): it shows your technical level in transparent way but it can be used as excuse to block the job level progress by the managers and it takes a lot of time/months (in already busy days) to prepare it.

High decision makers are almost always chinese (plans to put more locals in high positions, but it is very small proportion of the high positions)

Technical/expert support are most chinese, it helps if you can speak chinese, but otherwise you will find that you are slower than your chinese colleagues in getting the info/solving the problem.

Work days can be very long (no real notion of free time/work hours/rest hours, you can get calls any day any time of the day)

review_title: A great place for high performers
pros:
Company culture gives 3rd and 4th chance in any domain they work in if they are a consistent performer no matter their current skill and position. Not a lot of big players give that. Most people under value the chance to change domains in a company and seems to give more focus on "Free Lunch". 
This company deserves more credit than the negative reviews given by people who had one dimentional view or their subjective view point. There is a strong regulation and process for employee growth and oppurtunity to take addition responsibility if a person wishes it. One of the rare companies in the tech industry where a reportee can grow beyond their manager in position and compensation easily if they are self-driven.
cons: Recent pandemic put brakes on some business verticals expansions which drove company to focus on high skilled talent which is reasonable view, but some negative news around the company made it a bit tough to onboard people who could do great things in the platform provided by the company. Its truly sad that those guys will never get to experience what huawei provides to talented engineers.
